bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, December 29, 1947

div1.p: Kean discusses the honorary degree given to Reed by Harvard University. Reed considered this one of the greatest honors in his lifetime. There is also a discussion of the proper quotation for the honorary tablet outside of the room where Reed died.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, December 29, 1947
div1.opener:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
29 Dec. '47
My dear Colonel Hench
div1.p:
Do you remember the conversation
which Alice when she was in Wonderland
had with the melancholy mouse? Mine
is a long and a sad tale said the mouse.
I see that it is long but why is it sad?
said Alice. So my tale is sad but I will
try not to make it too long. Your good
letter of the 9th with the pictures of the room
in which Major Reed died came about the
15th Of course I will be glad to coin a phrase
for the tablet. It is chiefly a matter of counting,
not words, but letters as we were required
to do in the inscriptions for the Jefferson memo-
rial, where the architect was a stern task-
master and there was the severe limitation
that we had to use the exact words of
T.J. who was a free spender of words as
of money. I think your suggestion as
to the inscription is excellent, but I
have not yet counted the letters. Do you
know that the phrase “He gave to man
control over that dreadful plague yellow
fever” was the citation that President
Elliott of Harvard (a master of words) put
as the citation of the degree conferred by him
2
as President of Harvard University. HeReed went
on to receive it and it pleased him more
than any other honor conferred on him
in his life-time. It came to me as his
best friend in the S.G.O. to have charge of his
funeral and to select, as the Q.M. Dept. permitted
me to do, the location of his grave. Mrs Reed
agreed with me that this admirable phase
should be the inscription on his tomb stone
and it is there today. I think that it
would be admirable for the Am. Soc. of
Tropical medicine to give a bronze tablet, in
which case they would make the inscription.
If the building should be pulled down
it should be placed in an appropriate
place, on another building on the same location
or in a museum.

Returning to the date when your letter came:
We have had in Wash. a near-epidemic of a
severe form of influenza of the virus type. I
came down with it about the time your letter
arrived, and my desk was piled high with
cards and letters. I was in bed 4 days and
had a slow and languid convalescence.
Meanwhile my wife Cornelia came down
on the 18th with a much more severe form
and is now still in bed, tho improving.
We spent a most unhappy Christmas. We
could not get a doctor till next day. He said
there was no pneumonia or other complication
except the inevitable bronchitis which is still with
her.

I must stop here. My only chance to get this in todays mail is the part-time maid
who is now going and cannot be stayed. Cornelia is now improving.
div1.closer:
Greetings to Mrs
Hench thanks for card Yours Kean
BRIG. GEN. JEFFERSON R. KEAN, RETD.
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
P.S. to letter of 29 Dec. '47
Dear Col. Hench
When I had my long and sad tale'
cut short this morning. I forgot one
thing which I had in mind to tell you.
Mrs. Franck came to see us recently
to bring Mrs Kean some copies which
she had made of a paper for her.
I asked her casually if she had heard
from you recently and she replied that she
AC
K
had not, she had not even learned if her
work had been satisfactory. I said
that you had been away from your office
a good deal recently and that you were
an extremely busy man, and suggested that
she send you a note to ask if the MSS had
been received and was satisfactory. She
seemed to have some hesitation about doing
so however, so I told her I would mention it
when I wrote to you. ‘Nuf Sed’ as our colored
citizens would say.
Cordially yours
J.R. Kean
